abstract.p: Patrick McEnroe is returning to tennis as player/owner of New York Hamptons, latest entrant in nine-team DuPont World Team Tennis Professional League; fete is held on Irish naval flagship to honor Irish-government-sponsored construction of replica of 1845 ship, one of 'famine ships' that transported over 1.5 million people from starving Ireland beset by potato famine; Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra concert held July 4 marked 100th anniversary of date Louis Armstrong often claimed as birthdate; orchestra plans 13-month celebration of Armstrong that will end on his actual centennial; photos (M)

A Mac Returns To Tennis Racket

It is true that PATRICK McENROE made good his escape from the pressures of the professional tennis tour two years ago, finding gainful employment as a color commentator for ESPN and CBS. Then he took on the role of morning sports guy on the DON IMUS radio program.
So why is he now fielding his own new tennis team as a player/owner?
''I still love to play,'' he said. Really? ''Yes, and this gives me an impetus to get my posterior in shape,'' he said, laughing.

Mr. McEnroe, 34, is the force behind the New York Hamptons, which will kick off -- er, serve up -- their first season at home on July 13 in East Quogue at the 1,500-seat Sportime in the Hamptons club.

Why locate the New York Hamptons in, well, the Hamptons? ''I grew up on the Island,'' he said, ''my parents have a place there, and I wanted to play where there was a good tennis crowd, a good tennis aura.''

The New York Hamptons are the newest entrant in the nine-team DuPont World Team Tennis Professional League. It features four-member coed singles and doubles teams playing rapid-paced tennis. Among Mr. McEnroe's partners are JIM COURIER and MONIQUE VIELE; they expect to play such legends as MONICA SELES and MARTINA NAVRATILOVA during the team's three-week season.

But next week, he may log in some sleepy practices if the Imus show resumes, since Mr. McEnroe has to punch the clock at 5:30 a.m. The show went to reruns after the host broke five ribs in a June 18 riding accident. ''It's up in the air as to whether he'll be back next Monday,'' Mr. McEnroe said of the I-Patient.
Irish Remember A Different OpSail

Call it the Energizer OpSail: it just keeps on going and going. Last night, 250 revelers gathered aboard the Irish naval flagship, the L.E. Eithne, to honor the Irish-government-sponsored construction of a replica of an 1845 bark, the Jeanie Johnston. The original tall ship was one of the ''famine ships'' that transported more than 1.5 million people from a starving Ireland beset by the potato famine.

''Since it's an Irish event, there's an appropriate song,'' said BRIAN KENNEDY, a star of the Broadway show ''Riverdance,'' who lifted his tenor in a rendition of ''Lift the Wings.'' This second-act ballad, about the famine, has the lyrics ''Lift the wings that carry me away from here -- and fill the sail that breaks the line to home.''

His audience included BARRIE ROBINSON, Ireland's consul general, and MICHAEL SMITH, Ireland's defense minister. ''In the new millennium,'' said the 33-year-old Mr. Kennedy, ''it's good to be reminded of how Irish people arrived in this country.''
Satchmo Birthday A Movable Feast
The fireworks may have cooled, but there is a burning question raised by ''Hotter Than That,'' the Independence Day concert in Liberty State Park played by the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra.

Billed as a ''celebration of the 100th birthday of Louis Armstrong,'' the program featured the orchestra's artistic director, WYNTON MARSALIS, presenting such Armstrong hits as ''Ain't Misbehavin.' ''

Armstrong often claimed that July 4 was his birthday, but subsequent research unearthed a birth certificate ''showing that he was born Aug. 4, 1901,'' said ROB GIBSON, the orchestra's executive producer and director.
''But the mythical birthdate is the one that should be celebrated,'' Mr. Gibson said, ''because it's the one that Armstrong celebrated for his whole life.''
Yes, but how does Mr. Gibson reconcile this discrepancy? The July 4 concert ''was the kickoff to a 13-month celebration of Louis Armstrong,'' he said, a world tour of the jazz orchestra.
And when will this birthday bash end? ''On Aug. 4, 2001,'' Mr. Gibson said.
GLENN COLLINS
